Graphical abstract The conversion of guaiacol, a lignin model compound, over SiO2-supported Re metal, oxide and sulfide catalysts in a batch reactor at 300°C and 5MPa of hydrogen pressure were studied. The oxide catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation with a loading of 2.5atom of Re per nm2 of support. The sulfide and metal catalysts were prepared by sulfidation and reduction, respectively, of the Re oxide catalyst. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Catalytic activity was correlated with XPS analysis of the post-reaction catalysts. The ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was the most active and selective towards deoxygenated products, and this was attributed to increase in the concentration of metal oxide defect sites (due to in situ partial reduction of the oxide catalyst during the reaction). This result reveals the high potential of ReOx/SiO2 catalyst for bio-oil upgrading because it shows, among other things, that it is unnecessary to add undesirable sulfiding agent to maintain catalytic activity. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Guaiacol ReS2 ReOx Re metallic 1 Introduction The transformation of lignocellulosic biomass by the fast pyrolysis process has received increasing attention because of its potential to generate second-generation fuels and value-added chemicals. In addition, biomass-derived fuels would not require substantial modification of existing distribution systems and engines. An additional incentive for the use of biofuels as an alternative to fossil fuels is its lower generation of greenhouse gas emissions. The bio-oil generated from fast pyrolysis is a complex mixture containing many compounds such as carboxylic acids, alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, sugars, furans, phenols and guaiacols compounds [1–3]. Substituted phenols like guaiacols and syringols are derived from the thermal decomposition of lignin, one of the main components of woody biomass. The conversion of lignin is fraught with considerable challenges and extensive efforts are underway to unlock its potential as a feedstock for the biorefinery concept. The highly oxygenated nature of bio-oil limits their direct application as transportation fuels, and thus requires upgrading to reduce or remove the oxygen content. A partial removal of oxygen will suffice for the production of valuable chemicals. This represents an attractive alternative to non-renewable fossil feedstock for the production of commodity chemicals. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) has been the most widely employed upgrading method. Guaiacol (2-methoxyphenol) has been widely used as a lignin model compound to elucidate the mechanism and assess the efficiency of HDO catalysts. Different active phases, including metal sulfides [4–10] and metals [11–18], have been investigated as catalysts for the HDO of guaiacol. Other non-traditional catalysts such as ReS2 catalysts [19,20] and Mo2N catalysts [21,22] have also been utilized, and have exhibited similar trends in selectivities. These catalysts were also shown to be as active as, if not more active than, conventional sulfide catalysts for HDO. The studies on these catalysts have also shed insight on parameters which controls the reactivity. For example, the catalytic activity of metal catalysts has been shown to be dependent on the active metal phases and the supports. The distribution of reaction products from guaiacol conversion has been related mainly to the interplay between support properties and the active phase. It has been established that selectivity is highly dependent on the nature of the support. However, the role of the active phase on selectivity has not been adequately explored. A fundamental understanding of the effect of different catalytically active phases on reactivity is critical to rational catalyst design, as well as to improve the bio-oil upgrading process from both a technical and an economic standpoint. In order to ascertain the role played by the active phase it is imperative to utilize an inert support. Limited attention has been given to ReS2-based catalysts, even though they have been shown to be highly active for both hydrodesulfurization (HDS) and HDO reactions [23]. Ruiz et al. [19] found that ReS2/ZrO2 catalysts were 2.8 times more active than a commercial NiMoS/Al2O3 catalyst for the conversion of guaiacol. Recently, Sepúlveda et al. [20] studied the co-processing of guaiacol with HDS of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene over ReS2/SiO2 and ReS2/Al2O3 catalysts in a batch reactor: the authors found that the HDO rate increased only for the ReS2/Al2O3 catalyst, while the HDS rate decreased for both catalysts. The decrease in HDS rates was attributed to a competitive adsorption between guaiacol and 4,6-DMDBT compounds on the active sites. In this study, we present the performance of different Re phases (Re metallic, Re oxide, and Re sulfide) supported on SiO2 for the conversion of guaiacol in a batch reactor. Silica support, which is a catalytically inert support, was chosen to provide insight on the relationship between active phase and HDO reactivity. The catalysts were prepared with the same Re surface density, and characterized pre- and post-reaction by XPS to observe the changes in surface composition during the reaction. In contrast to the Re sulfide phase, the Re metal and Re oxide phases have not been previously studied for the HDO of guaiacol. The results showed there were inherent differences between the catalytic behaviour of the Re oxide, the metallic Re and the Re sulfide. The catalytic activity of these Re catalysts were compared with a conventional sulfided NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supported rhenium-based catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of an aqueous solution of NH4ReO4 (Aldrich, 99%) on a SiO2 support (Grace Davison 432). The silica support was used without any further purification. The catalyst was prepared with a loading of 2.5atm of Re per nm2 of support. The impregnated catalysts were left for maturation at room temperature for 24h, dried at 393K for 12h, and then calcined at 573K for 0.5h. The calcined sample was divided into three parts: the first part, in the calcined state, was referred to as ReOx/SiO2 catalyst; the second part was reduced at 673K for 4h under flowing H2 and denoted as Re/SiO2 catalyst, and the last part was sulfided at 673K for 4h under 10% H2S/N2 mixture and referred to as ReS2/SiO2. The Re content was determined by ICP–OES using the Re emission line of 221.426nm. The conventional NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst (HR436) was sulfided at 673K for 4h under 10% H2S/H2 mixture using the same procedure used for the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts The BET surface area (S BET) and total pore volume (V p ) of the silica support and the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst were determined from nitrogen isotherms at 77K using a Micromeritics-TriStar II 3020 instrument. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) studies were carried out in a quartz cell on a conventional system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. In each experiment, 100mg of the sample was heated under 5% H2/Ar with a flow of 50cm3 min−1. The sample was heated at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 from 298 to 1323K. Transmission electronic microscopy (TEM) images of Re/SiO2 were obtained with a Jeol Model JEM-1200 EXII System. Samples were ground and dispersed in methanol, then transferred to a cupper grid (methanol dispersion method). To obtain the Re particle size, a histogram study of the micrographs for over 300 particles of Re/SiO2 catalyst was performed using Image Tool 3.0 software. XPS measurements were performed using a VG Escalab 200R electron spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical electron analyzer and a Mg Kα (1253.6eV) excitation source. Energy corrections were performed using the Si line of the SiO2 support at 103.4eV as an internal reference. The samples were treated as previously stated, cooled to room temperature, flushed with N2, stored in flasks containing n-heptane, and transferred into the pretreatment chamber of the spectrometer. The XPS analyses of these samples were categorized as pre-reaction. After the HDO reaction, the spent catalyst was transferred into flasks containing n-dodecane, and analyzed by XPS. The intensity of the peaks was estimated by calculating the integral of each peak after subtracting an S-shaped background and fitting the experimental curve to a combination of Gaussian/Lorentzian lines. 2.3 Catalytic tests The HDO of guaiacol was carried out in an autoclave reactor operating in batch mode. The liquid reactant feed, consisting of guaiacol (0.232molL−1) in n-dodecane (80mL) with hexadecane (0.0341molL−1) as an internal standard, was introduced into the reactor. Then, approximately 0.200g of the selected catalyst was added. As previously indicated, the Re/SiO2 and ReS2/SiO2 catalysts were prepared from the ex situ reduction and sulfidation, respectively, of the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst, and quickly transferred to the reactor to prevent oxidation. The system was closed, and N2 was bubbled through the solution for 10min with a flow of 100mLmin−1 to purge any air in the system. Still under N2 atmosphere, the reactor was heated to the reaction temperature of 573K with stirring. The reaction timer was initiated when the reaction temperature was reached and the pressure was adjusted to 5MPa by H2. The pressure was kept constant during the course of the experiment. Condensed samples were taken periodically during the reaction, and identified by a gas chromatograph (Perkin Elmer—Clarus 680) coupled with a GCMS-SQ8T, and quantified by a gas chromatograph (Perkin-Elmer—Clarus 400) equipped with a Flame Ionization Detector (FID) and a CP-Sil 5 column (Agilent, 30m×0.53mm×1.0μm film thickness). The specific rate for the total conversion of guaiacol was deduced from the initial slope of conversion as a function of time plot according to the following equation: (1) r s = b × n m where r s is the specific rate (molg−1 s−1), b represents the initial slope of the conversion vs. time plot (dimensionless), n is the initial moles of guaiacol (mol), and m is the mass of catalyst (g). The deoxygenation (HDO) rate was calculated from the conversion of guaiacol to O-free compounds (benzene, cyclohexane, cyclohexene, and analogous compounds). The selectivities (%) were determined at 20% and 60% of guaiacol conversion, according to the following equation: (2) S % = X i X T × 100 where X i is the percentage of product formation i, and X T is the guaiacol conversion. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The surface area (S BET), total pore volume (V p ), micropore volume (V o ) and mesopore volume (V m ) of the support and the calcined catalyst are shown in Table 1 . The data shows that after Re impregnation and calcination, there is a decrease in the surface area and the pore volume; more specifically, there is a significant decrease, approximately 30%, in the mesopore volume. This suggests that the Re species were highly dispersed in the mesopores of the SiO2, and that pore mouth blockage was practically absent. This is in agreement with the similar pore diameter values obtained for these samples. Fig. 1 shows the TPR profile of ReOx/SiO2 and Re/SiO2 catalysts. The ReOx/SiO2 TPR curve shows a single, well-resolved peak observed at around 600K, suggesting a one-step reduction of ReOx species to Re metal. A similar result was previously obtained by Arnoldy et al. [24], who suggested that the sharpness of the reduction peaks can be enhanced by the presence of Re0 through a mechanism of autocatalysis. The TPR of Re/SiO2 catalyst does not show any hydrogen consumption peaks, suggesting that ReOx was completely reduced (in agreement with hydrogen uptake calculations showing complete reduction). In summary, these results clearly confirm that the reduction conditions used to prepare Re/SiO2 catalyst are sufficient for obtaining mainly Re metallic species. Fig. 2 shows the pre- and post-reaction TEM images recorded for the Re/SiO2 catalyst and the histogram of the Re particle size distribution over the SiO2 support. The TEM before the reaction showed highly homogenous spherical particles attributed to metallic Re. The corresponding Re particle size distribution showed a narrow distribution centred at 2.8nm. Okal et al. previously reported a similar Re particle size distribution [25]. The TEM of the spent catalyst showed an increase in the Re particle sizes: the particle size distribution shows a broad distribution centred at 3.8nm. These results suggest a sintering of Re metallic particles under operating reaction conditions. Fig. 3 shows the XPS of the Re 4f region of ReOx/SiO2, ReS2/SiO2, and Re/SiO2 catalysts before and after HDO reaction. Curve fitting of the whole spectra revealed one and three partially overlapped doublets depending on the catalyst, each one containing Re 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 peaks. Table 2 summarizes the binding energies (BE) of the most intense Re 4f7/2 component of the 4f doublet, their relative proportion (showed in parentheses), and the surface Re/Si and S/Re atomic ratios for each catalysts before and after reaction. Table 2 shows that the fresh ReOx/SiO2 catalyst displayed two Re 4f7/2 contributions with BEs of 45.6eV and 47.2eV: the BE of 47.2eV can be assigned to Re7+ corresponding to Re2O7 species, in agreement with Naor et al. [26]; the BE of 45.6eV is in the range of Re7+ corresponding to ReO4 − species [26], in agreement with the previously reported result by Escalona et al. [27]. The authors found by DR spectra the presence of ReO4 − and Re2O7 species in supported rhenium oxide under the same calcination conditions used in this study. Table 2 also shows a higher contribution of the ReO4 − species compared to the Re2O7 species, consistent with previously reported results [27]. On the other hand, the XPS analysis of the fresh ReS2/SiO2 catalyst displayed only one Re 4f7/2 contribution with BE of 41.7eV, assigned to ReS2 [27]. However, the value of S/Re atomic ratio was lower than 2.0 expected for ReS2, suggesting the formation of ReS(2−x) species which is in agreement with previous findings [28,29]. The XPS spectra of the fresh Re/SiO2 catalyst displayed two Re 4f7/2 components with BEs of 40.4eV and 42.4eV, attributed to Re0 [25,30] and Re4+ [25,30], respectively. The relative proportion values show Re0 species as the predominant species. Taking into account the complete reduction observed by TPR, the presence of Re4+ species can be explained by re-oxidation during the brief exposure to ambient during the transfer of the sample to the chamber of the spectrophotometer. The XPS analysis of the catalysts after reaction showed significant changes in the surface composition of the catalysts. Table 2 shows that the post-reaction ReOx/SiO2 catalyst displayed three Re 4f7/2 contributions with BEs of 41.4eV, 42.9eV and 46.2eV: the 42.9eV can be assigned to Re4+corresponding to ReO2 species [30]; the 46.2eV is assigned to Re7+ corresponding to ReO4 − species [26,30]; and the 41.4eV could be assigned to species between Re0 and Re4+ [25,26]. This indicates a partial reduction of the as-prepared ReOx/SiO2 catalyst under reaction conditions, a possible effect of the H2 reactant. Furthermore, the relative proportions of the different rhenium species of the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst after reaction show that the Re7+ species were the principal species. The XPS analysis of ReS2/SiO2 catalyst after the hydrodeoxygenation reaction presented only one Re 4f7/2 peak with BE similar to that of the corresponding fresh catalyst; furthermore, no traces of oxide phase were detected despite the oxygenated feed. This suggests no significant modification of the surface composition under reaction conditions. In contrast, the surface species of the Re/SiO2 catalyst were strongly affected by the reaction conditions. In fact, the XPS analysis of the used Re/SiO2 catalyst displayed three Re 4f7/2 contributions with BEs of 41.0eV, 43.3eV and 46.0eV. The BEs of 43.3eV and 46.0eV were assigned to ReO2 [25,26] and ReO4 − [26,30] species, respectively. Meanwhile, the BE of 41.0eV can be assigned to species between Re0 and Re4+ [25,26]. These results suggest that the Re/SiO2 catalyst was not stable under the reaction conditions, and was more susceptible to oxidation probably due to the presence of water produced during the reaction. The Re/Si atomic ratio from XPS spectra of pre- and post-reaction catalysts are presented in Table 2. For the unused catalyst, the Re/Si atomic ratio decreased in the order: Re/SiO2 >ReS2/SiO2 >ReOx/SiO2 catalysts. Based on previously reported work by Matsuda et al. [31] on the reduction of MoO3, this trend can be attributed to the contraction of metal lattice and fracturing of crystals as a result of oxygen removal during reduction of ReOx, leading to smaller particles of metallic Re and, consequently, increase in coverage of the support. In addition, Topsøe and Topsøe [32] have suggested the breaking of metal/oxide support bonds and some structural rearrangement upon reduction and sulfiding. It is conceivable that the mobility of the rhenium species during reduction and sulfidation led to increase in the apparent coverage of the silica support surface by the Re species. The largest Re/Si atomic ratio observed for Re/SiO2 catalyst suggests that metallic Re has a higher dispersion over SiO2. The Re/Si atomic ratio of the used catalysts revealed interesting contrasting behaviours in the relative dispersion after the HDO reaction: in comparison to the as-prepared catalysts, the post-reaction Re/Si atomic ratio for ReS2/SiO2 and Re/SiO2 catalysts decreased by 30% and 82%, respectively, while that of the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst increased by 72%. The substantial decrease in Re/Si atomic ratio for Re/SiO2 after reaction suggests the occurrence of particle agglomeration on the surface and decrease in Re dispersion, in good agreement with the corresponding TEM result. This confirms that sintering of Re metal particles occurred during the reaction. Similarly for the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst, the post-reaction decrease of Re/Si atomic ratio indicates a decrease in Re dispersion, albeit less-pronounced. Unfortunately, TEM cannot be used to estimate the particle size of Re sulfide because the lamellar structure decomposes into spherical particles of metallic Re under the electron beam [29]. In contrast with the Re/SiO2 and ReS2/SiO2 catalysts, the post-reaction increase in Re/Si atomic ratio for the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst suggests a re-dispersion of ReOx species over the SiO2 support. In addition, Table 2 shows that the S/Re atomic ratio for ReS2/SiO2 catalyst increases after reaction, suggesting an increase in the degree of sulfidation of the surface species. This result is quite surprising due to the absence of any sulfiding agent in the reaction feed, and consequently indicates the robustness of the ReS2 phase under typical HDO reaction conditions. This increase can be attributed to an excess of sulfur on the surface by loss of Re dispersion. 3.2 Catalytic activity Fig. 4 illustrates the evolution of the conversion of guaiacol over the different SiO2-supported Re phase catalysts. Several products were detected during the transformation of guaiacol. Negligible conversions were obtained using bare silica support, indicating that guaiacol conversions were associated exclusively with the Re phases. There were clear differences between the behaviour of the catalysts as shown in Fig. 4: with Re/SiO2 and ReS2/SiO2 catalysts, guaiacol was mainly converted to phenol even at high conversion, while phenol was formed at low conversion but rapidly transformed to benzene and cyclohexane over the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst. In addition to phenol, catechol was an intermediary product at low conversion with the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst. Minor amounts of anisole, methylphenol, cyclohexanol and methanol were detected with the ReS2/SiO2 and Re/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 4b and c). The main deoxygenated compounds observed over the ReOx/SiO2 and Re/SiO2 catalysts were cyclohexane and BTX (benzene, toluene and xylene), while cyclohexane was the main HDO product over the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, traces of hexane, cyclohexene, methylcyclohexane and BTX (benzene toluene and xylene) were identified with the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst, while conversion over the Re/SiO2 catalyst produced trace amounts of methylcyclohexane, benzene, toluene and hexane. At high conversion, the minor products for ReOx/SiO2 catalyst were anisole, methoxycyclohexanone, methanol and methylcyclohexane. Methylphenol, methylcyclohexanone, cyclohexane, and hexane were only detected as traces. Furthermore for the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst, the concentration of phenol, anisole, cyclohexanol, and BTX (mostly benzene) first increased with reaction time and then decreased afterwards, indicating that these compounds were intermediate products (Fig. 4a). The different reaction products observed indicate that the transformation of guaiacol over these catalysts followed the reaction scheme depicted in Fig. 5 . This reaction scheme is in accordance with the scheme proposed by Laurent and Delmon [4], Bui et al. [5,6] and Nimmanwudipong et al. [11]. The reaction scheme depicting the reactivity of the ReOx/SiO2 and Re/SiO2 catalysts show catechol as an intermediary compound, even though catechol was not detected for these catalysts. It is possible for catechol to be formed and then quickly transformed to phenol, which is in agreement with the very high conversion rate of catechol shown in Fig. S1 given in the Supplementary data. The three catalysts had proclivities towards the cleavage of the methoxy-aromatic carbon bond to produce phenol. This route is commonly referred to the direct demethoxylation (DMO) pathway, as depicted in Fig. 5 [4–6]. The second reaction pathway, only detected for the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst, involved hydrogenolysis of the OCH3 bond (demethylation route, DME) on guaiacol to form catechol [4–6], which was then transformed to phenol. This is consistent with the evolution of phenol observed in Fig. 4b. Furthermore, guaiacol could be dehydroxylated to form anisole. Subsequently, phenol can undergo consecutive deoxygenation and hydrogenation (HYD) reactions to form benzene and cyclohexane over all the catalysts. Benzene may also have been produced through demethoxylation of anisole, in agreement with the mechanism proposed by Mimmanwudipong et al. [11]. The formation of both deoxygenated and hydrogenated products indicates that these different Re phases on silica can act as bifunctional catalysts in hydrodeoxygenation reactions. Moreover, traces of hexane were observed for all the catalysts, possibly through cracking of cyclohexane. On the other hand, the existence of hydrogenation sites on the ReO x /SiO2 and ReS2/SiO2 catalysts were confirmed by the production of methoxycyclohexanone (from the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring of guaiacol) and cyclohexanol (via the hydrogenation of either methoxycyclohexanone or phenol) Finally, the formation of methyl-compounds (methylcyclohexane, methylphenols, etc.) may be attributed to methyl transfer from the methoxyl groups to the aromatic ring through acid catalyzed transalkylation reactions, as suggested by Zhu et al. [33]. Fig. 6 shows the product distribution as a mole percentage of all guaiacol-derived products calculated at 20% guaiacol conversion. Fig. 6 shows that all the catalysts displayed a similar distribution, with phenol as the main reaction product (60–75%). Also, appreciable amounts of completely deoxygenated products such as benzene and cyclohexane were obtained, particularly for the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst. The elimination of oxygen from phenol is thermodynamically more difficult than the cleavage of aromatic carbon–methoxy bond [34]. In fact, it is one of the most difficult bonds to cleave in bio-oils, and thus the ability of the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst to convert phenol to oxygen-free compound while minimizing hydrogen consumption makes them attractive for the lignocellulosic biorefinery concept. Fig. 7 illustrates the initial total and hydrodeoxygenation rates for all the Re-based catalysts and the commercial NiMoS catalyst (used as reference). Overall, the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst displayed the highest activity and reached complete conversion after 3h of reaction time (shown in Fig. 4). The activity was lowest over the Re/SiO2 catalyst, which reached 60% conversion after 4h, while the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst exhibited intermediate activity reaching 80% conversion after 4h of reaction. The ReOx/SiO2 catalyst also displayed a slightly higher hydrodeoxygenation rate than the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst. This result, coupled with the highest guaiacol conversion obtained for the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst, suggests that oxygen vacancy could be very active for hydrogenolysis reactions. This finding is consistent with previous studies that have suggested that the presence of metal oxide facilitates the activation of the oxo-group on the substrate [35]. Furthermore, it has been reported that electron-deficient ReOx sites favour the adsorption of electron-rich carbon–carbon, as suggested by Sibeijn et al. [36] during alkenes metathesis reaction [37–39]. Fig. 7 also shows that the total reaction rate of ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was 2.9 times higher than commercial NiMoS/Al2O3 catalyst; correspondingly, the hydrodeoxygenation rate of the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was also 4.8 times higher than the commercial catalyst. This result, in addition to the high selectivity to benzene and cyclohexane, strongly suggests that the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst possesses high potential for the valorization of lignin-derived compounds. 3.3 Demethylation mechanisms and active sites with Re-based catalysts Understanding the mechanism involved in the conversion of guaiacol over Re active phases requires some degree of knowledge of the adsorption behaviour of the substrate on the surface of the active phase. The adsorption of guaiacol has been investigated using DFT calculations, on MoS2 M-edge, where the most stable mode was found to be the η 1 adsorption by the OH group of the substrate [40]. This adsorption mechanism could be considered the same for other Re active phases; however, in our proposal we cannot disregard the degree of inclination of the aromatic ring on top of the catalyst surface due to the π-electron rich system of guaiacol. This catalyst surface–π electron system interaction could only be ignored with compounds such as furfural, where the electron density is clearly higher in the carbonyl group or the oxygen atom over the aromatic ring [41]. Another point that we have to consider is that catechol as an intermediary product was not detected over the ReOx/SiO2 and Re/SiO2 catalysts, suggesting an additional mechanism of reaction or different type of active site that can take place exclusively or in parallel with the other proposed pathways. First, coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUS) confer a Lewis acid character on the Re metal, oxide and sulfide catalysts. The proximity of the hydroxyl group of guaiacol to these Lewis acid sites results in a transfer of an electron pair from the oxygen atom to the metallic centre (Fig. 8a, A). This situation could give rise to: (a) enhancement of the electron density near the substituents on the aromatic ring (Fig. 8a, B), or (b) facilitation of the CO ether bond cleavage, as a consequence of the keto-enol equilibrium shift to try to counterbalance the electron density transfer to the metallic centre (Fig. 8a, C). This interaction (Fig. 8b, A) is followed by a shift of the aromatic ring over the catalyst, favouring secondary stabilizing interactions; consequently, this arrangement should leave the methoxy group closer to the surface (Fig. 8b, B), in line with the findings of Peralta et al. [42] who proposed an interaction of the aromatic ring of benzaldehyde with Cs metal when it is adsorbed on CsNaX zeolite catalysts. The first step of the reaction may involve a rapid hydrogenation of the double bond (HOCsp2 Csp2 OCH3) of the aromatic ring to produce a single CC bond; this assumption is based on the fact that the cleavage of a CO σ-bond is considered more energetically demanding when the bond is attached to an aromatic ring which delocalizes the out-of plane oxygen lone-pair orbital (Fig. 9 , pathway A) [43]. Another possibility to consider is the hydrogenation of the CO keto form of the methoxy group (Fig. 9, pathway B); the advantage of this situation is that a double CO bond is more reactive than a CC bond and precludes the generation of hydrogenated products in the 3,4- or 2,3-position. The second step involves a H+ attack from the catalyst on the methoxy group to generate +OHCH3, followed by the elimination of methanol which allows restoration of the aromaticity. Along both pathways, phenol can be desorbed from the catalyst with the formation of methanol as a by-product, which is consistent with the observed light weight product composition shown in Fig. 6. 4 Conclusion The hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol, a lignin model compound, was studied over silica-supported Re oxide, Re metal, and Re sulfide catalysts. The reduced and sulfided Re catalysts were prepared from the Re oxide sample. The activity of the catalysts decreased in the order: ReOx/SiO2 >ReS2/SiO2 >Re/SiO2. This trend shows that the best active sites for HDO are the ones present on the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst. However, the Re active phases on the ReOx/SiO2, ReS2/SiO2 and Re/SiO2 catalysts are not stable over the support under the operating conditions. The catalysts displayed similar product distributions, calculated at 20% guaiacol conversion, with phenol as the principal product. This result indicates that all the catalysts were highly effective in converting guaiacol into phenol, and hence could find application in the initial stabilization of bio-oil. In addition, phenol can be used industrially as a precursor to many materials and chemicals. The selectivity after 4h of reaction differed significantly: the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was highly selective towards benzene and cyclohexane while the ReS2/SiO2 and Re/SiO2 catalysts principally produced phenol. The surprisingly high deoxygenation activity for the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was attributed to the presence of oxygen vacancies, which are believed to be the best active site for HDO reaction. This finding is analogous to HDS studies which showed that sulfur vacancies are the best active sites for HDS reactions. The ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was almost three times more active than a commercial NiMoS/Al2O3 catalyst. This study underlined the strong potential of ReOx/SiO2 catalyst for the valorization of depolymerized lignin compounds. K. Leiva is indebted to CONICYT for doctoral grant. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of guaiacol, a lignin model compound, over SiO2-supported Re metal, oxide and sulfide catalysts in a batch reactor at 300°C and 5MPa of hydrogen pressure were studied. The oxide catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation with a loading of 2.5atom of Re per nm2 of support. The sulfide and metal catalysts were prepared by sulfidation and reduction, respectively, of the Re oxide catalyst. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Catalytic activity was correlated with XPS analysis of the post-reaction catalysts. The ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was the most active and selective towards deoxygenated products, and this was attributed to increase in the concentration of metal oxide defect sites (due to in situ partial reduction of the oxide catalyst during the reaction). This result reveals the high potential of ReOx/SiO2 catalyst for bio-oil upgrading because it shows, among other things, that it is unnecessary to add undesirable sulfiding agent to maintain catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodeoxygenation of 2-methoxyphenol over different Re active phases supported on SiO2 catalysts
